Incident.Summary: Vehicle was stopped for multiple violations. Upon approach of the vehicle, the odor of an alcoholic beverage was emitting from the vehicle. SFST's was conducted and the driver was placed under arrest for DUI/DWI. Search incident to arrest was made and a Polymer 80 firearm (Ghost gun) was located from the vehicle.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
In-Car camera and body worn camera operational.

Scene Processing:

During the course of the traffic stop, the driver was placed under arrest driving under the influence of alcohol. A search incident to arrest was conducted and one (1) Polymer 80 .40 Caliber pistol was located on the front passenger seat in a black plastic bag. The items recovered were placed on property record P-343762 according to MSP policy and procedure. 

Physical Evidence:

The following items were stored on Property Record P-343762 in a handgun box and stored on MSP Forms 67 and 63:

One (1) Polymer 80 .40 Caliber pistol, (Slide Model #PF940SC) (No serial #). (P-343762)

One (1) black Polymer 10 round Magazine. (P-343762)

Nine (9) .40 caliber ammunition. (P-343762)

All property was processed per Maryland State Police policy and procedures and placed in the Maryland State Police Barrack Evidence Locker.

Defendant: Willis, Justin Noel

Date of Birth: 10/11/1996

Time of arrest: 0231 hours

Location: Giles Place, in the area of, Vivian Adams Drive, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland 20601.

Maryland identification: MD-10272119384

DUI#: 23-145

1st DUI

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING

*Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police.

*Trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement through Charles County Sheriff's Office.

NARRATIVE/ VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1):

On 08/26/2023, at approximately 0211 hours, I, Tpr. Tripp #7333 with the Maryland State Police La Plata Barrack, was on patrol southbound Route 5, in the area of, Post Office Road, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland 20601 in lane two, when I observed a white Toyota Camry, bearing Maryland registration 5CD5040, stopped pass the white stop sign line at a steady circular red signal on southbound Route 5, at Post Office Road, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland 20601 in lane one. Once the light turned to a steady circular green signal, I then observed the vehicle traveling over the posted 35 Mile Per Hour (MPH) speed limit. I initiated a pace of 55 MPH and staying approximately one car length behind the vehicle keeping equal speed and equal distance from Post Office Road to Vivian Adams Drive. While pacing the vehicle, I observed the vehicle cross approximately one tire length from lane one to lane two for approximately two seconds before realigning back into lane one. I then observed the vehicle cross approximately one tire length from lane one to lane two for approximately two seconds before realigning back into lane one. I then activated my emergency equipment to stop the vehicle at Giles Place at Vivian Adams Drive, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland 20601.
 

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2):

I made contact with the driver and requested his driver's license and registration card, which he displayed only his passport identification. I was able to identify the driver through his passport identification as, Willis, Justin Noel (A.A/M, DOB: 10/11/1996). While speaking with Willis, I observed his eyes were bloodshot and glassy and his speech slurred. I then asked Willis where he was coming from, he advised a pool party. I then asked Willis if he had consumed any alcoholic beverages, he advised, "a couple drinks." CCSO assisted with the traffic stop. I requested Willis to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Test’s (SFST’s), which he agreed to take. As Willis approached the front of his vehicle, I continued to detect the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3):

While standing in front of Willis’ vehicle, I asked Willis if he wears glasses or contacts, he advised, No. I asked if there were any medical conditions that I should be aware of, Willis advised, No. I asked Willis if he is a diabetic or have high blood pressure, he advised, No. I asked Willis if he had any head injuries or concussions, he advised, No. I then asked Willis is there any physical issues that I should be aware of before conducting the test, he advised, No. I then asked Willis if he is able to perform the Walk and Turn test (WAT) and the One Leg Stand test (OLS), he advised, Yes.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS TEST: (6/6 clues observed).

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) test. The tip of my pen was used as the test's stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Willis’ eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. His pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking with no resting nystagmus. He was positioned in a manner to ensure the headlights of passing traffic would not interfere with the test results. 

Willis displayed equal pupil size, equal tracking and no resting nystagmus in both eyes.

Willis displayed lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes.

Willis displayed nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes.

Willis displayed nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes.

VERTICAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS:

Willis did not display vertical gaze nystagmus in both eyes.

WALK AND TURN: (7/8 clues observed).

Prior to Willis performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Willis was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe. He was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and to remain in that position until told to begin. He was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight-line touching heel to toe on every step. He was instructed to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Willis was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to turn completely around. Willis was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. He was instructed once he began the test he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. Willis advised to me; he understood the test before beginning.

Willis wore light colored sneakers for this test.

Willis could not keep his balance before beginning the test.

Willis missed heel-to-toe step on his second, seventh, eighth, and ninth step, on his first set of nine steps.

Willis stepped off-line on his first, seventh, and ninth step, on his first set of nine steps.

Willis raised his arms on his first step, on his first set of nine steps.

Willis took ten steps instead of nine as instructed, on his first set of nine steps.

Willis stopped on his third step, on his second set of nine steps.

Willis stepped off-line on his second, third, and fifth step, on his second set on nine steps.

Willis missed heel-to-toe step on his third, sixth, and eighth, on his second set of nine steps.

Willis took ten steps instead of nine as instructed, on his second set of nine steps.

ONE LEG STAND: (3/4 clues observed)

Prior to Willis performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be performed. He was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his sides while the instructions were given. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off of the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. Willis advised he understood the test.

Willis raised his right foot for this test.

0-10 seconds

Willis raised his arms at 1 and 10 seconds.

Willis placed his foot down at 1, 2, and 10 seconds.

Willis swayed at 8 seconds

11-20

Willis placed his foot down at 20 seconds.

21-30

Willis placed his foot down at 25 seconds

Willis swayed at 25 seconds.

Willis was offered to take the Preliminary Breath Test (PBT) and refused to take to the test.

Arrest:

-Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person.

-Bloodshot and glassy eyes.

-Slurred speech.

-Admission to consuming alcoholic beverages.

-Clues displayed from the Standardized Field Sobriety Test.

Willis was placed under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol at 0231 hours. Once Willis was arrested, I then conducted a search incident to an arrest on his person and the vehicle. On the rear passenger side floorboard, I located one (1) DonJulio Tequila alcoholic beverage (40% alc/vol), partially empty. On the front passenger seat, in a black plastic bag, I located One (1) Polymer 80 firearm, loaded with nine (9) rounds in the magazine (no round in the chamber) at 0239 hours. Once I advised Willis of the firearm, he immediately advised he did not know the firearm was in the vehicle. Willis was then read is Miranda Rights at 0246 hours and he chose not to waiver his rights. Willis was then read his DR-15 Advice of Rights at 0302 hours, and he refused to take the Intoximeter Test. Willis was then transported to the Maryland State Police La Plata Barrack along with the firearm for further processing.

Willis was then transported to Charles County Detention Center and was charged with the following:

1 1454: Loaded Handgun in vehicle CR, 4-203(a)(1)(v)

1 0175 Handgun in vehicle CR, 4-203 

Willis received the following citations:

TA-21-902(a1i) Driving under the influence of alcohol.

TA-21-902(b1i) Driving while impaired by alcohol.

TA-21-901.1(a) Reckless Driving.

TA-21-901.1(b) Negligent Driving.

TA-21-201(a1) Driver failure to obey traffic control device instructions.

TA-21-309(b) Driver changing lanes when unsafe.

TA-21-309(b) Unsafe Lane changing.

TA-21-801.1 Exceeding posted maximum speed limit: 55 MPH in a posted 35 MPH zone.

TA-21-707(a) Driver failure to stop at stop line.

TA-13-409(b) Driver failure display registration card.

TA-16-112(c) Driver failure to display license.

I responded to the barrack and processed the firearm according to MSP policy.

The following property was checked and verified by Sgt. Norman #5237:

One (1) Polymer 80 .40 Caliber pistol (Slide Model #PF940SC) (No serial #). One black Polymer 80, 10 Round Magazine, Nine (9) .4 Caliber rounds of ammunition. (P-343762)

The following items listed above were packaged and stored following MSP policy and procedures.

Due to the firearm being a “Ghost gun”, the firearm is untraceable according to the Gun center.

At 0425 hours, I contacted ST Ditoto #5416 of the Maryland State Police Gun Unit via cellphone and notified him of the above details and requested the firearm to be test fired.

On 09/04/2023, at approximately 1040 hours, I witnessed ST Ditoto test fire the Polymer 80. The weapon was found to be operable and capable of being fired.

All the above events occurred in Charles County, Maryland.

Case closed.

IncidentProperty.Description: One (1) black and gray Polymer 80 pistol with a ten (10) round magazine, and nine (9) .40 caliber ammunition rounds.
